RP   FUNCTION.
RX   PubMed=17261657; DOI=10.1161/CIRCULATIONAHA.106.645499;
RA   Peng J., Raddatz K., Molkentin J.D., Wu Y., Labeit S., Granzier H.,
RA   Gotthardt M.;
RT   "Cardiac hypertrophy and reduced contractility in hearts deficient in
RT   the titin kinase region.";
RL   Circulation 115:743-751(2007).
RN   [7]
RP   PHOSPHORYLATION [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS] AT SER-9144, AND IDENTIFICATION
RP   BY MASS SPECTROMETRY [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS].
RC   TISSUE=Liver;
RX   PubMed=17242355; DOI=10.1073/pnas.0609836104;
RA   Villen J., Beausoleil S.A., Gerber S.A., Gygi S.P.;
RT   "Large-scale phosphorylation analysis of mouse liver.";
RL   Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 104:1488-1493(2007).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Key component in the assembly and functioning of
CC       vertebrate striated muscles. By providing connections at the level
CC       of individual microfilaments, it contributes to the fine balance
CC       of forces between the two halves of the sarcomere. The size and
CC       extensibility of the cross-links are the main determinants of
CC       sarcomere extensibility properties of muscle. In non-muscle cells,
CC       seems to play a role in chromosome condensation and chromosome
CC       segregation during mitosis. Might link the lamina network to
CC       chromatin or nuclear actin, or both during interphase.
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q8WZ42, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16702235,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17261657}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: ATP + a protein = ADP + a phosphoprotein.
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q8WZ42}.
CC   -!- COFACTOR:
CC       Name=Mg(2+); Xref=ChEBI:CHEBI:18420;
CC         Evidence={ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q8WZ42};
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: Full activation of the protein kinase domain
CC       requires both phosphorylation of Tyr-33203, preventing it from
CC       blocking the catalytic aspartate residue, and binding of Ca/CALM
CC       to the C-terminal regulatory tail of the molecule which results in
CC       ATP binding to the kinase. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q8WZ42}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with MYOM1, MYOM2, tropomyosin and myosin.
CC       Interacts with actin, primarily via the PEVK domains and with
CC       MYPN. Interacts with FHL2, NEB, CRYAB, LMNA/lamin-A and
CC       LMNB/lamin-B. Interacts with TCAP/telethonin and/or ANK1 isoform
CC       Mu17/ank1.5, via the first two N-terminal immunoglobulin domains.
CC       Interacts with TRIM63, TRIM55, ANKRD1, ANKRD2, ANKRD23, and CAPN3
CC       through several Ig domains. Interacts with NBR1 through the
CC       protein kinase domain (By similarity). Interacts with CMYA5 (By
CC       similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000305}. Nucleus
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q8WZ42}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=3;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=A2ASS6-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2;
CC         IsoId=A2ASS6-2; Sequence=VSP_052606, VSP_052608;
CC       Name=3;
CC         IsoId=A2ASS6-3; Sequence=VSP_052606, VSP_052607, VSP_052609;
CC         Note=Gene prediction based on EST data. {ECO:0000305};
CC   -!- DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE: Expressed in cardiac muscle from 8 dpc and in
CC       skeletal muscle from 9 dpc. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9440711}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: ZIS1 and ZIS5 regions contain multiple SPXR consensus
CC       sites for ERK- and CDK-like protein kinases as well as multiple SP
CC       motifs. ZIS1 could adopt a closed conformation which would block
CC       the TCAP-binding site (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q8WZ42}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The PEVK region may serve as an entropic spring of a chain
CC       of structural folds and may also be an interaction site to other
CC       myofilament proteins to form interfilament connectivity in the
CC       sarcomere. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q8WZ42}.
CC   -!- PTM: Autophosphorylated.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the protein kinase superfamily. CAMK
CC       Ser/Thr protein kinase family. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 132 fibronectin type-III domains.
CC       {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU00316}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 144 Ig-like (immunoglobulin-like) domains.
CC       {ECO:0000255}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 18 Kelch repeats. {ECO:0000255}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 protein kinase domain.
CC       {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU00159}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 12 RCC1 repeats. {ECO:0000255}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 15 TPR repeats. {ECO:0000255}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 17 WD repeats. {ECO:0000255}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Transcription factor that seems to function
CC       synergistically with the POU domain protein TST-1/OCT6/SCIP. Could
CC       confer cell specificity to the function of other transcription
CC       factors in developing and mature glia (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Acts as a transcriptional repressor. Involved in
CC       recruitment of functional SIN3A complexes to DNA. Represses
CC       transcription at least in part through the activity of an
CC       associated histone deacetylase (HDAC). May also repress
CC       transcription in a SIN3A-independent manner through recruitment of
CC       functional AES complexes to DNA (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q96QT6}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with SIN3A in a complex composed of HDAC1,
CC       SAP30 and SIN3A. Interacts with AES (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q96QT6}.

RP   INTERACTION WITH TIAM1.
RX   PubMed=20361982; DOI=10.1016/j.jmb.2010.03.047;
RA   Shepherd T.R., Klaus S.M., Liu X., Ramaswamy S., DeMali K.A.,

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Cell surface proteoglycan that bears both heparan
CC       sulfate and chondroitin sulfate and that links the cytoskeleton to
CC       the interstitial matrix.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with CDCP1 (By similarity). Interacts (via C-
CC       terminus) with TIAM1 (via PDZ domain). {ECO:0000250,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:20361982}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane; Single-pass type I membrane
CC       protein. Secreted. Note=Shedding of the ectodomain produces a
CC       soluble form.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=2;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=P18828-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC         Note=Major isoform.;
CC       Name=2;
CC         IsoId=P18828-2; Sequence=VSP_007542;
CC         Note=Minor isoform.;
CC   -!- PTM: Shedding is enhanced by a number of factors such as
CC       heparanase, thrombin or EGF. Also by stress and wound healing.
CC       PMA-mediated shedding is inhibited by TIMP3 (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the syndecan proteoglycan family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

RC   TISSUE=Embryonic fibroblast;
RX   PubMed=19131326; DOI=10.1074/mcp.M800451-MCP200;
RA   Sweet S.M., Bailey C.M., Cunningham D.L., Heath J.K., Cooper H.J.;
RT   "Large scale localization of protein phosphorylation by use of
RT   electron capture dissociation mass spectrometry.";
RL   Mol. Cell. Proteomics 8:904-912(2009).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Myosins are actin-based motor molecules with ATPase
CC       activity. Unconventional myosins serve in intracellular movements.
CC       May be involved in the remodeling of the actin cytoskeleton. Binds
CC       actin with high affinity both in the absence and presence of ATP
CC       and its mechanochemical activity is inhibited by calcium ions.
CC       Also acts as a GTPase activating protein on Rho.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm, cell cortex {ECO:0000250}.
CC       Cytoplasm, perinuclear region {ECO:0000250}. Cytoplasm,
CC       cytoskeleton {ECO:0000250}. Note=In undifferentiated cells
CC       colocalizes with F-actin in the cell periphery while in
CC       differentiated cells its localization is cytoplasmic with the
CC       highest levels in the perinuclear region. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=3;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=Q9QY06-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2; Synonyms=Q;
CC         IsoId=Q9QY06-2; Sequence=VSP_003363;
CC       Name=3; Synonyms=C;
CC         IsoId=Q9QY06-3; Sequence=VSP_003364, VSP_003365;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed in the brain, heart, muscle and
CC       inner ear.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the TRAFAC class myosin-kinesin ATPase
CC       superfamily. Myosin family. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 4 IQ domains. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00116}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 myosin motor domain. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 phorbol-ester/DAG-type zinc finger.
CC       {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU00226}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 Ras-associating domain.
CC       {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU00166}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 Rho-GAP domain. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00172}.
CC   -!- CAUTION: Represents an unconventional myosin. This protein should
CC       not be confused with the conventional myosin-9 (MYH9).
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Plays an important role in the normal skeletal
CC       development. May regulate the expression of other genes involved
CC       in chondrogenesis by acting as a transcription factor for these
CC       genes (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.

RP   INTERACTION WITH DIAPH1; DIAPH2 AND MAPRE1.
RX   PubMed=15311282; DOI=10.1038/ncb1160;
RA   Wen Y., Eng C.H., Schmoranzer J., Cabrera-Poch N., Morris E.J.S.,
RA   Chen M., Wallar B.J., Alberts A.S., Gundersen G.G.;
RT   "EB1 and APC bind to mDia to stabilize microtubules downstream of Rho
RT   and promote cell migration.";
RL   Nat. Cell Biol. 6:820-830(2004).
RN   [7]
RP   INTERACTION WITH SCRIB.
RX   PubMed=16611247; DOI=10.1111/j.1365-2443.2006.00954.x;
RA   Takizawa S., Nagasaka K., Nakagawa S., Yano T., Nakagawa K.,
RA   Yasugi T., Takeuchi T., Kanda T., Huibregtse J.M., Akiyama T.,
RA   Taketani Y.;
RT   "Human scribble, a novel tumor suppressor identified as a target of
RT   high-risk HPV E6 for ubiquitin-mediated degradation, interacts with
RT   adenomatous polyposis coli.";
RL   Genes Cells 11:453-464(2006).
RN   [8]
RP   FUNCTION.
RX   PubMed=19893577; DOI=10.1038/embor.2009.233;
RA   Kawasaki Y., Tsuji S., Muroya K., Furukawa S., Shibata Y., Okuno M.,
RA   Ohwada S., Akiyama T.;
RT   "The adenomatous polyposis coli-associated exchange factors Asef and
RT   Asef2 are required for adenoma formation in Apc(Min/+)mice.";
RL   EMBO Rep. 10:1355-1362(2009).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Tumor suppressor. Promotes rapid degradation of CTNNB1
CC       and participates in Wnt signaling as a negative regulator. APC
CC       activity is correlated with its phosphorylation state. Activates
CC       the GEF activity of SPATA13 and ARHGEF4. Plays a role in
CC       hepatocyte growth factor (HGF)-induced cell migration (By
CC       similarity). Required for MMP9 up-regulation via the JNK signaling
CC       pathway in colorectal tumor cells. Acts as a mediator of ERBB2-
CC       dependent stabilization of microtubules at the cell cortex. It is
CC       required for the localization of MACF1 to the cell membrane and
CC       this localization of MACF1 is critical for its function in
CC       microtubule stabilization (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Forms homooligomers and heterooligomers with APC2.
CC       Interacts with PDZ domains of DLG1 and DLG3. Associates with
CC       catenins. Binds axin. Interacts with MAPRE2 and MAPRE3 (via C-
CC       terminus). Found in a complex consisting of ARHGEF4, APC and
CC       CTNNB1. Interacts with ARHGEF4 (via N-terminus) (By similarity).
CC       Interacts with MAPRE1 (via C-terminus); probably required for APC
CC       targeting to the growing microtubule plus ends. Interacts with
CC       DIAPH1 and DIAPH2. Interacts with SCRIB; may mediate targeting to
CC       adherens junctions of epithelial cells. Interacts with SPATA13
CC       (via N-terminus and SH3 domain). Interacts with ASAP1 (via SH3
CC       domain) (By similarity). Found in a complex composed of MACF1,
CC       APC, AXIN1, CTNNB1 and GSK3B. Interacts at the cell membrane with
CC       AMER1 and AMER2 (via ARM repeats) (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell junction, adherens junction
CC       {ECO:0000250}. Cytoplasm, cytoskeleton {ECO:0000250}. Cell
CC       projection, lamellipodium {ECO:0000250}. Cell projection, ruffle
CC       membrane {ECO:0000250}. Cytoplasm {ECO:0000250}. Cell membrane
CC       {ECO:0000250}. Note=Associated with the microtubule network at the
CC       growing distal tip of microtubules. Accumulates in the
CC       lamellipodium and ruffle membrane in response to hepatocyte growth
CC       factor (HGF) treatment. The MEMO1-RHOA-DIAPH1 signaling pathway
CC       controls localization of the phosophorylated form to the cell
CC       membrane (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=4;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=Q61315-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2;
CC         IsoId=Q61315-2; Sequence=VSP_004116;
CC       Name=3;
CC         IsoId=Q61315-3; Sequence=VSP_004117;
CC       Name=4;
CC         IsoId=Q61315-4; Sequence=VSP_004116, VSP_004117;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed in liver, spleen, kidney, heart,
CC       lung, brain, stomach, intestine, testis and ovary.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The microtubule tip localization signal (MtLS) motif;
CC       mediates interaction with MAPRE1 and targeting to the growing
CC       microtubule plus ends. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- PTM: Phosphorylated by GSK3B. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- PTM: Ubiquitinated, leading to its degradation by the proteasome.
CC       Ubiquitination is facilitated by Axin. Deubiquitinated by
CC       ZRANB1/TRABID (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the adenomatous polyposis coli (APC)
CC       family. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 7 ARM repeats. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00259}.

RT   "Solution structure of the Tudor domain of Tudor domain containing
RT   protein 3 from mouse.";
RL   Submitted (JUN-2006) to the PDB data bank.
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Scaffolding protein that specifically recognizes and
CC       binds dimethylarginine-containing proteins. In nucleus, acts as a
CC       coactivator: recognizes and binds asymmetric dimethylation on the
CC       core histone tails associated with transcriptional activation
CC       (H3R17me2a and H4R3me2a) and recruits proteins at these arginine-
CC       methylated loci. In cytoplasm, may play a role in the assembly
CC       and/or disassembly of mRNA stress granules and in the regulation
CC       of translation of target mRNAs by binding Arg/Gly-rich motifs
CC       (GAR) in dimethylarginine-containing proteins (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of mRNA stress granules. Interacts with FMR1,
CC       FXR1, FXR2, EWSR1, FUS, SERBP1, EEF1A1 and DDX3X or DDX3Y, and
CC       with the small nuclear ribonucleoprotein-associated proteins SNRPB
CC       and SNRPN. Interacts with 'Lys-48'-linked tetra-ubiquitin, but not
CC       with monoubiquitin or 'Lys-63'-linked ubiquitin chains. May
CC       interact with the exon junction complex (EJC) composed at least of
CC       CASC3, EIF4A3, MAGOH and RBM8A (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000250}. Nucleus
CC       {ECO:0000250}. Note=Predominantly cytoplasmic. Associated with
CC       actively translating polyribosomes and with mRNA stress granules
CC       (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=3;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=Q91W18-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2;
CC         IsoId=Q91W18-2; Sequence=VSP_034485;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available.;
CC       Name=3;
CC         IsoId=Q91W18-3; Sequence=VSP_037054;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available.;
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The Tudor domain specifically recognizes and binds
CC       asymmetric dimethylation of histone H3 'Arg-17' (H3R17me2a) and
CC       histones H4 'Arg-3', 2 tags for epigenetic transcriptional
CC       activation. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 Tudor domain. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00211}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 UBA domain. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00212}.

RP   MASS SPECTROMETRY [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS].
RC   TISSUE=Embryonic fibroblast;
RX   PubMed=23806337; DOI=10.1016/j.molcel.2013.06.001;
RA   Park J., Chen Y., Tishkoff D.X., Peng C., Tan M., Dai L., Xie Z.,
RA   Zhang Y., Zwaans B.M., Skinner M.E., Lombard D.B., Zhao Y.;
RT   "SIRT5-mediated lysine desuccinylation impacts diverse metabolic
RT   pathways.";
RL   Mol. Cell 50:919-930(2013).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Fodrin, which seems to be involved in secretion,
CC       interacts with calmodulin in a calcium-dependent manner and is
CC       thus candidate for the calcium-dependent movement of the
CC       cytoskeleton at the membrane.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Like erythrocyte spectrin, the spectrin-like proteins are
CC       capable of forming dimers which can further associate to
CC       tetramers. Interacts (via C-terminal spectrin repeats) with TRPC4.
CC       Interacts with CALM and EMD. Interacts with isoform 1 of ACP1.
CC       Identified in a complex with ACTN4, CASK, IQGAP1, MAGI2, NPHS1 and
CC       SPTBN1. Interacts with SHANK3 (via ANK repeats) (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm, cytoskeleton. Cytoplasm, cell
CC       cortex. Note=Expressed along the cell membrane in podocytes and
CC       presumptive tubule cells during glomerulogenesis and is expressed
CC       along lateral cell margins in tubule cells. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=2;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=P16546-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2;
CC         IsoId=P16546-2; Sequence=VSP_022093;
CC   -!- PTM: Phosphorylation of Tyr-1176 decreases sensitivity to cleavage
CC       by calpain in vitro. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the spectrin family. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 3 EF-hand domains. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00448}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 SH3 domain. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00192}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 23 spectrin repeats. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Calcium-independent receptor of low affinity for alpha-
CC       latrotoxin, an excitatory neurotoxin present in black widow spider
CC       venom which triggers massive exocytosis from neurons and
CC       neuroendocrine cells. Receptor propably implicated in the
CC       regulation of exocytosis (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Forms a heterodimer, consisting of a large extracellular
CC       region (p120) non-covalently linked to a seven-transmembrane
CC       moiety (p85). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=2;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=Q8JZZ7-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2;
CC         IsoId=Q8JZZ7-2; Sequence=VSP_010110, VSP_010111;
CC   -!- PTM: Proteolytically cleaved into 2 subunits, an extracellular
CC       subunit and a seven-transmembrane subunit. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the G-protein coupled receptor 2 family.
CC       LN-TM7 subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

RN   [21]
RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (1.6 ANGSTROMS) OF 405-613 IN COMPLEX WITH
RP   HEMIMETHYLATED DNA.
RX   PubMed=18772891; DOI=10.1038/nature07249;
RA   Arita K., Ariyoshi M., Tochio H., Nakamura Y., Shirakawa M.;
RT   "Recognition of hemi-methylated DNA by the SRA protein UHRF1 by a
RT   base-flipping mechanism.";
RL   Nature 455:818-821(2008).
RN   [22]
RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (2.19 ANGSTROMS) OF 419-628 IN COMPLEX WITH
RP   HEMIMETHYLATED DNA.
RX   PubMed=18772888; DOI=10.1038/nature07280;
RA   Hashimoto H., Horton J.R., Zhang X., Bostick M., Jacobsen S.E.,
RA   Cheng X.;
RT   "The SRA domain of UHRF1 flips 5-methylcytosine out of the DNA
RT   helix.";
RL   Nature 455:826-829(2008).
RN   [23]
RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (1.99 ANGSTROMS) OF 417-628.
RX   PubMed=19077538; DOI=10.4161/epi.4.1.7370;
RA   Hashimoto H., Horton J.R., Zhang X., Cheng X.;
RT   "UHRF1, a modular multi-domain protein, regulates replication-coupled
RT   crosstalk between DNA methylation and histone modifications.";
RL   Epigenetics 4:8-14(2009).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Multidomain protein that acts as a key epigenetic
CC       regulator by bridging DNA methylation and chromatin modification.
CC       Specifically recognizes and binds hemimethylated DNA at
CC       replication forks via its YDG domain and recruits DNMT1
CC       methyltransferase to ensure faithful propagation of the DNA
CC       methylation patterns through DNA replication. In addition to its
CC       role in maintenance of DNA methylation, also plays a key role in
CC       chromatin modification: through its tudor-like regions and PHD-
CC       type zinc fingers, specifically recognizes and binds histone H3
CC       trimethylated at 'Lys-9' (H3K9me3) and unmethylated at 'Arg-2'
CC       (H3R2me0), respectively, and recruits chromatin proteins. Enriched
CC       in pericentric heterochromatin where it recruits different
CC       chromatin modifiers required for this chromatin replication. Also
CC       localizes to euchromatic regions where it negatively regulates
CC       transcription possibly by impacting DNA methylation and histone
CC       modifications. Has E3 ubiquitin-protein ligase activity by
CC       mediating the ubiquitination of target proteins such as histone H3
CC       and PML. It is still unclear how E3 ubiquitin-protein ligase
CC       activity is related to its role in chromatin in vivo. May be
CC       involved in DNA repair. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12058012,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12084726, ECO:0000269|PubMed:14993289,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15361834, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17673620,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17994007, ECO:0000269|PubMed:21268065,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:21489993}.
CC   -!- PATHWAY: Protein modification; protein ubiquitination.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with DNMT1; the interaction is direct.
CC       Interacts with USP7; leading to its deubiquitination. Interacts
CC       with HDAC1, but not with HDAC2. Interacts with UHRF1BP1. Interacts
CC       with PML. Interacts with EHMT2. Binds hemimethylated CpG
CC       containing oligonucleotides. Interacts with histones H3, H1 and
CC       H2B. Interacts with DNMT3A and DNMT3B.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14993289, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15361834,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17994007, ECO:0000269|PubMed:18772888,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18772891, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19056828,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19798101, ECO:0000269|PubMed:21268065}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00358, ECO:0000269|PubMed:10984098,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11161719, ECO:0000269|PubMed:14993289,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17994007, ECO:0000269|PubMed:21489993,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8634372}. Note=Localizes to replication foci.
CC       Enriched in pericentric heterochromatin. Also localizes to
CC       euchromatic regions.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=2;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=Q8VDF2-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2;
CC         IsoId=Q8VDF2-2; Sequence=VSP_044395;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed in thymus, testis, spleen and lung.
CC       Within testis, expressed in almost all cells except elongated
CC       spermatids. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10984098,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9880673}.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: Up-regulated in proliferating cells, and down-regulated
CC       in quiescent or differentiated cells. Early induced by E1A in
CC       post-mitotic cells. Down-regulated by aphidicolin.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10984098, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11161719,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12058012, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8634372}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The tudor-like regions specifically recognize and bind
CC       histone H3 unmethylated at 'Arg-2' (H3R2me0), while the PHD-type
CC       zinc finger specifically recognizes and binds histone H3
CC       trimethylated at 'Lys-9' (H3K9me3). The tudor-like regions
CC       simultaneously recognizes H3K9me3 through a conserved aromatic
CC       cage in the first tudor-like subdomain and unmodified H3K4
CC       (H3K4me0) within a groove between the tandem subdomains
CC       (PubMed:21489993). The linker region plays a role in the formation
CC       of a histone H3-binding hole between the reader modules formed by
CC       the tudor-like regions and the PHD-type zinc finger by making
CC       extended contacts with the tandem tudor-like regions.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21489993}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The YDG domain (also named SRA domain) specifically
CC       recognizes and binds hemimethylated DNA at replication forks (DNA
CC       that is only methylated on the mother strand of replicating DNA)
CC       (PubMed:17994007). The YDG domain contains a binding pocket that
CC       accommodates the 5-methylcytosine that is flipped out of the
CC       duplex DNA. 2 specialized loops reach through the resulting gap in
CC       the DNA from both the major and the minor grooves to read the
CC       other 3 bases of the CpG duplex. The major groove loop confers
CC       both specificity for the CpG dinucleotide and discrimination
CC       against methylation of deoxycytidine of the complementary strand
CC       (PubMed:18772888). The YDG domain also recognizes and binds 5-
CC       hydroxymethylcytosine (5hmC). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17994007,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18772888}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The RING finger is required for ubiquitin ligase activity.
CC   -!- PTM: Phosphorylation at Ser-303 of the linker region decreases the
CC       binding to H3K9me3. Phosphorylation at Ser-639 by CDK1 during M
CC       phase impairs interaction with USP7, preventing deubiquitination
CC       and leading to degradation by the proteasome (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- PTM: Ubiquitinated; which leads to proteasomal degradation.
CC       Autoubiquitinated; interaction with USP7 leads to deubiquitination
CC       and prevents degradation. Ubiquitination and degradation takes
CC       place during M phase, when phosphorylation at Ser-639 prevents
CC       intereaction with USP7 and subsequent deubiquitination.
CC       Polyubiquitination may be stimulated by DNA damage.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21268065}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Mice display a sensitization to DNA damage
CC       and replication block, and die in mid-gestation.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12084726}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 PHD-type zinc finger. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00146}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 RING-type zinc finger.
CC       {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU00175}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 ubiquitin-like domain.
CC       {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU00214}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 YDG domain. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00358}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: May have oxidoreductase activity. Regulates p38 MAP
CC       kinase activity by mediating stress activation of p38alpha/MAPK14
CC       and specifically regulating MAPK14 signaling. Indirectly promotes
CC       phosphorylation of MAPK14 and activation of ATF2. The
CC       phosphorylation of MAPK14 requires upstream activity of MAP2K4 and
CC       MAP2K6. Recruited on chromatin, recognizes and binds trimethylated
CC       'Lys-36' of histone H3 (H3K36me3) (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with MAPK14. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The A.T hook DNA-binding domain is required for the
CC       interaction with MAPK14. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The PWWP domain probably mediates the binding to H3K36me3.
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: The conserved NAD-binding sites and sequence
CC       similarity to plant dehydrogenases suggest that this protein may
CC       have oxidoreductase activity.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the 3-hydroxyisobutyrate dehydrogenase
CC       family. NP60 subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 A.T hook DNA-binding domain. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 PWWP domain. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00162}.

RN   [4]
RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [LARGE SCALE MRNA].
RX   PubMed=15489334; DOI=10.1101/gr.2596504;
RG   The MGC Project Team;
RT   "The status, quality, and expansion of the NIH full-length cDNA
RT   project: the Mammalian Gene Collection (MGC).";
RL   Genome Res. 14:2121-2127(2004).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: ATP-dependent RNA helicase involved in mRNA export from
CC       the nucleus. Rather than unwinding RNA duplexes, DDX19 functions
CC       as a remodeler of ribonucleoprotein particles, whereby proteins
CC       bound to nuclear mRNA are dissociated and replaced by cytoplasmic
CC       mRNA binding proteins (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: ATP + H(2)O = ADP + phosphate.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000250}. Nucleus, nuclear
CC       pore complex. Nucleus membrane {ECO:0000250}; Peripheral membrane
CC       protein {ECO:0000250}; Cytoplasmic side {ECO:0000250}.
CC       Note=Nuclear pore complex cytoplasmic fibrils.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Found in testis, heart, brain, liver, skeletal
CC       muscle, and kidney.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The N-terminal extension helix acts as an autoinhibitory
CC       domain, preventing ATP hydrolysis, unless the N-terminus of the
CC       protein is displaced by RNA binding, allowing cleft closure to
CC       bring key side chains into position for catalysis. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the DEAD box helicase family. DDX19/DBP5
CC       subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 helicase ATP-binding domain.
CC       {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU00541}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 helicase C-terminal domain.
CC       {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU00542}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Subunit of clathrin-associated adaptor protein complex 1
CC       that plays a role in protein sorting in the trans-Golgi network
CC       (TGN) and endosomes. The AP complexes mediate the recruitment of
CC       clathrin to membranes and the recognition of sorting signals
CC       within the cytosolic tails of transmembrane cargo molecules.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Adaptor protein complex 1 (AP-1) is a heterotetramer
CC       composed of two large adaptins (gamma-type subunit AP1G1 and beta-
CC       type subunit AP1B1), a medium adaptin (mu-type subunit AP1M1 or
CC       AP1M2) and a small adaptin (sigma-type subunit AP1S1 or AP1S2 or
CC       AP1S3). Interacts with MARCH11 (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q10567:AP1B1 (xeno); NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-1040251, EBI-1171303;
CC       P22892:Ap1g1; NbExp=5; IntAct=EBI-1040251, EBI-1040262;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Golgi apparatus. Cytoplasmic vesicle,
CC       clathrin-coated vesicle membrane; Peripheral membrane protein;
CC       Cytoplasmic side. Note=Component of the coat surrounding the
CC       cytoplasmic face of coated vesicles located at the Golgi complex.
CC   -!- PTM: Phosphorylation of membrane-bound AP1M1/AP1M2 increases its
CC       affinity for sorting signals. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the adaptor complexes medium subunit
CC       family. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 MHD (mu homology) domain.
CC       {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU00404}.

RP   ACETYLATION [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS] AT LYS-40 AND LYS-236, AND
RP   IDENTIFICATION BY MASS SPECTROMETRY [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS].
RC   TISSUE=Embryonic fibroblast;
RX   PubMed=23806337; DOI=10.1016/j.molcel.2013.06.001;
RA   Park J., Chen Y., Tishkoff D.X., Peng C., Tan M., Dai L., Xie Z.,
RA   Zhang Y., Zwaans B.M., Skinner M.E., Lombard D.B., Zhao Y.;
RT   "SIRT5-mediated lysine desuccinylation impacts diverse metabolic
RT   pathways.";
RL   Mol. Cell 50:919-930(2013).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Involved in the alternative regulation of pre-mRNA
CC       splicing; its RNA helicase activity is necessary for increasing
CC       tau exon 10 inclusion and occurs in a RBM4-dependent manner. Binds
CC       to the tau pre-mRNA in the stem-loop region downstream of exon 10.
CC       The rate of ATP hydrolysis is highly stimulated by single-stranded
CC       RNA. Involved in transcriptional regulation; the function is
CC       independent of the RNA helicase activity. Transcriptional
CC       coactivator for estrogen receptor ESR1 and androgen receptor AR.
CC       Increases ESR1 AF-1 domain-mediated transactivation and ESR1 AF-1
CC       and AF-2 domains transcriptional synergistic activity. Synergizes
CC       with DDX17 and SRA1 RNA to activate MYOD1 transcriptional activity
CC       and involved in skeletal muscle differentiation. Transcriptional
CC       coactivator for p53/TP53 and involved in p53/TP53 transcriptional
CC       response to DNA damage and p53/TP53-dependent apoptosis.
CC       Transcriptional coactivator for RUNX2 and involved in regulation
CC       of osteoblast differentiation. Acts as transcriptional repressor
CC       in a promoter-specicic manner; the function probbaly involves
CC       association with histone deacetylases, such as HDAC1. As component
CC       of a large PER complex is involved in the inhibition of 3'
CC       transcriptional termination of circadian target genes such as PER1
CC       and NR1D1 and the control of the circadian rhythms.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17011493, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17960593,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22767893}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: ATP + H(2)O = ADP + phosphate.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Identified in the spliceosome C complex. Interacts with
CC       RBM4; the interaction occurs in an RNA-independent manner.
CC       Interacts with AGO1 and AGO2. Interacts with ESR1; the interaction
CC       is enhanced by phosphorylation of ESR1 AF-1 domain. Interacts with
CC       AR, NCOA1, NCOA2, NCOA3, EP300, CREBBP, POLR2A, TP53, RUNX2 and
CC       HDAC1. Self-associates. Interacts with DDX17. Interacts with BRDT.
CC       The large PER complex involved in the repression of
CC       transcriptional termination is composed of at least PER2, CDK9,
CC       DDX5, DHX9, NCBP1 and POLR2A (active).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22570411, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22767893}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus, nucleolus {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- PTM: Sumoylated; sumoylation, promoted by PIAS1, promotes
CC       interaction with HDAC1 and transcriptional repression activity.
CC       Sumoylation also significantly increases stability, and reduces
CC       polyubiquitination (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- PTM: Polyubiquitinated, leading to proteasomal degradation.
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the DEAD box helicase family. DDX5/DBP2

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Ubiquitin-binding protein that interacts with the BRCA1-
CC       BARD1 heterodimer, and regulates its activity. Specifically binds
CC       'Lys-6'-linked polyubiquitin chains. Interaction with
CC       autoubiquitinated BRCA1, leads to inhibit the E3 ubiquitin-protein
CC       ligase activity of the BRCA1-BARD1 heterodimer (By similarity)
CC       Component of a complex required to couple deglycosylation and
CC       proteasome-mediated degradation of misfolded proteins in the
CC       endoplasmic reticulum that are retrotranslocated in the cytosol.
CC       Involved in ubiquitin-proteasome systems. {ECO:0000250,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16709668}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with BRCA1 and BARD1; interaction takes place
CC       when BRCA1 is not autoubiquitinated bur is strongly enhanced in
CC       the presence of autoubiquitinated BRCA1 (By similarity). Component
CC       of a complex required to couple retrotranslocation, ubiquitination
CC       and deglycosylation composed of NGLY1, SAKS1, AMFR, VCP and
CC       RAD23B. Interacts with HOMER2. Interacts directly with VCP.
CC       {ECO:0000250, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11562482,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15944415, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16709668}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15944415}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The UBA domain specifically recognizes and binds 'Lys-6'-
CC       linked polyubiquitin chains. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 UBA domain. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00212}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 UBX domain. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00215}.

RP   PHOSPHORYLATION [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS] AT SER-479, AND IDENTIFICATION
RP   BY MASS SPECTROMETRY [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS].
RC   TISSUE=Brain;
RX   PubMed=16452087; DOI=10.1074/mcp.T500041-MCP200;

RN   [9]
RP   PHOSPHORYLATION [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS] AT TYR-1237, AND IDENTIFICATION
RP   BY MASS SPECTROMETRY [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS].
RC   TISSUE=Brain;
RX   PubMed=18034455; DOI=10.1021/pr0701254;
RA   Ballif B.A., Carey G.R., Sunyaev S.R., Gygi S.P.;
RT   "Large-scale identification and evolution indexing of tyrosine
RT   phosphorylation sites from murine brain.";
RL   J. Proteome Res. 7:311-318(2008).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Plays a role in cytokinesis. Required for KIF14
CC       localization to the central spindle and midbody. Probable RHO/RAC
CC       effector that binds to the GTP-bound forms of RHO and RAC1. It
CC       probably binds p21 with a tighter specificity in vivo. Displays
CC       serine/threonine protein kinase activity. Plays an important role
CC       in the regulation of cytokinesis and the development of the
CC       central nervous system. Phosphorylates MYL9/MLC2 (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: ATP + a protein = ADP + a phosphoprotein.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9792683}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with TTC3 (By similarity). Homodimer
CC       (Probable). Directly interacts with KIF14 depending on the
CC       activation state (stronger interaction with the kinase-dead form).
CC       {ECO:0000250, ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9792683}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=5;
CC         Comment=Additional isoforms seem to exist.;
CC       Name=1; Synonyms=CRIK;
CC         IsoId=P49025-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2; Synonyms=CRIK-SK;
CC         IsoId=P49025-2; Sequence=VSP_012438, VSP_012439;
CC       Name=3; Synonyms=Citron;
CC         IsoId=P49025-3; Sequence=VSP_012436, VSP_012437;
CC       Name=4;
CC         IsoId=P49025-4; Sequence=VSP_016093;
CC       Name=5;
CC         IsoId=P49025-5; Sequence=VSP_016094, VSP_016095;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available.;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: A major signal was observed in testis and
CC       brain, but it was also detected in thymus, spleen, kidney, heart
CC       and lung. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11086988,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9792683}.
CC   -!- DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE: Detected at E10.5 with highest expression in
CC       the developing central nervous system. After E16.5 expression
CC       decreases and at two weeks after birth is restricted to the
CC       proliferating neuronal precursor cells in the external germinal
CC       layer of the cerebellum and subventricular migratory stream.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11086988}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Death before reaching adulthood, probably
CC       due to lethal epilepsy. Mice display severe defects in the
CC       olfactory bulbs, the hippocampus, and the cerebellum. These
CC       defects appear to result from impaired cytokinesis followed by the
CC       induction of apoptosis in specific neuroblast populations.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11086988}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the protein kinase superfamily. AGC Ser/Thr
CC       protein kinase family. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 AGC-kinase C-terminal domain.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 CNH domain. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00795}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 PH domain. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00145}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 phorbol-ester/DAG-type zinc finger.
CC       {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU00226}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 protein kinase domain.
CC       {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU00159}.

CC       Sequence=AAC72822.1; Type=Frameshift; Positions=396, 408; Evidence={ECO:0000305};
CC       Sequence=AAC72823.1; Type=Frameshift; Positions=396, 408; Evidence={ECO:0000305};
CC       Sequence=AAH23775.1; Type=Frameshift; Positions=1011; Evidence={ECO:0000305};

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Protein transport. Regulator of membrane traffic from
CC       the Golgi apparatus towards the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) (By
CC       similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with RIC1 and RGP1; the interactions are direct
CC       with a preference for RAB6A-GDP. Interacts with VSP52 and RABGAP1.
CC       Interacts with GCC2 (via its GRIP domain). Interacts with RAB6IP1
CC       (via its RUN 1 domain). Interacts with RAB6KIFL. Interacts with
CC       BICD1. Interacts with BICD2. Interacts with TMF1. Interacts (GTP-
CC       bound) with DYNLRB1; the interaction is direct (By similarity).
CC       Interacts with SCYL1BP1. Interacts with CCDC64; leads to its
CC       accumulation in the pericentrosomal region. Interacts with PIFO.
CC       Interacts (GTP-bound) with APBA1/MINT1 isoform 3, also called
CC       Mint1_826. {ECO:0000250, ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P20340,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18997784, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20360680,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:20643351, ECO:0000269|PubMed:23737971}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q921C5:Bicd2; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-444674, EBI-642984;
CC       A0JNT9:Ccdc64; NbExp=6; IntAct=EBI-444674, EBI-7893170;
CC       Q8TDW5:SYTL5 (xeno); NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-444674, EBI-2939487;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Golgi apparatus
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P20340}. Golgi apparatus membrane; Lipid-
CC       anchor.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=2;

RP   ISGYLATION.
RX   PubMed=16139798; DOI=10.1016/j.bbrc.2005.08.132;
RA   Giannakopoulos N.V., Luo J.K., Papov V., Zou W., Lenschow D.J.,
RA   Jacobs B.S., Borden E.C., Li J., Virgin H.W., Zhang D.E.;
RT   "Proteomic identification of proteins conjugated to ISG15 in mouse and
RT   human cells.";
RL   Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 336:496-506(2005).
RN   [4]
RP   FUNCTION IN EDITING ACTIVITY ON MISCHARGED TRNA(ALA).
RX   PubMed=20010690; DOI=10.1038/nature08612;
RA   Guo M., Chong Y.E., Shapiro R., Beebe K., Yang X.L., Schimmel P.;
RT   "Paradox of mistranslation of serine for alanine caused by AlaRS
RT   recognition dilemma.";
RL   Nature 462:808-812(2009).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Catalyzes the attachment of alanine to tRNA(Ala) in a
CC       two-step reaction: alanine is first activated by ATP to form Ala-
CC       AMP and then transferred to the acceptor end of tRNA(Ala). Also
CC       edits incorrectly charged tRNA(Ala) via its editing domain.
CC       {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03133, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20010690}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: ATP + L-alanine + tRNA(Ala) = AMP +
CC       diphosphate + L-alanyl-tRNA(Ala). {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-
CC       Rule:MF_03133}.
CC   -!- COFACTOR:
CC       Name=Zn(2+); Xref=ChEBI:CHEBI:29105;
CC         Evidence={ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03133};
CC       Note=Binds 1 zinc ion per subunit. {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-
CC       Rule:MF_03133};
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Monomer. {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03133}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03133}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: Consists of three domains; the N-terminal catalytic
CC       domain, the editing domain and the C-terminal C-Ala domain. The C-
CC       Ala domain, along with tRNA(Ala), serves as a bridge to
CC       cooperatively bring together the editing and aminoacylation
CC       centers thus stimulating deacylation of misacylated tRNAs (By
CC       similarity). The editing domain removes incorrectly charged amino
CC       acids from Gly-tRNA(Ala) and Ser-tRNA(Ala) to yield uncharged
CC       tRNA(Ala) and the amino acid. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- PTM: ISGylated. {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03133,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16139798}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the class-II aminoacyl-tRNA synthetase
CC       family. {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03133}.

CC   Copyrighted by the UniProt Consortium, see http://www.uniprot.org/terms
CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Inositol 5-phosphatase which has a role in clathrin-
CC       mediated endocytosis. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: 1-phosphatidyl-1D-myo-inositol 4,5-
CC       bisphosphate + H(2)O = 1-phosphatidyl-1D-myo-inositol 4-phosphate
CC       + phosphate.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Binds AMPH, SH3GL1, SH3GL2 and SH3GL3. Interacts with
CC       ASH/GRB2. Interacts with MYO1E (via SH3 domain) (By similarity).
CC       Interacts with PACSIN1, PACSIN2 and PACSIN3. {ECO:0000250,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11082044}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: Binds to EPS15 (a clathrin coat-associated protein) via a
CC       C-terminal domain containing three Asn-Pro-Phe (NPF) repeats.
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The C-terminal proline-rich region mediates binding to a
CC       variety of SH3 domain-containing proteins including AMPH, SH3GL1,
CC       SH3GL2, SH3GL3 and GRB2.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Iron sensor. Binds a 4Fe-4S cluster and functions as
CC       aconitase when cellular iron levels are high. Functions as mRNA
CC       binding protein that regulates uptake, sequestration and
CC       utilization of iron when cellular iron levels are low. Binds to
CC       iron-responsive elements (IRES) in target mRNA species when iron
CC       levels are low. Binding of a 4Fe-4S cluster precludes RNA binding
CC       (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Catalyzes the isomerization of citrate to isocitrate via
CC       cis-aconitate. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Citrate = isocitrate.
CC   -!- COFACTOR:
CC       Name=[4Fe-4S] cluster; Xref=ChEBI:CHEBI:49883;
CC         Evidence={ECO:0000250};
CC       Note=Binds 1 [4Fe-4S] cluster per subunit. {ECO:0000250};
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts (when associated with the 4Fe-4S) with FBXL5.
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the aconitase/IPM isomerase family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

RP   FUNCTION, AND DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE.
RX   PubMed=17537792; DOI=10.1242/dev.005033;
RA   Linton J.M., Martin G.R., Reichardt L.F.;
RT   "The ECM protein nephronectin promotes kidney development via integrin
RT   alpha8beta1-mediated stimulation of Gdnf expression.";
RL   Development 134:2501-2509(2007).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Integrin alpha-8/beta-1 functions in the genesis of
CC       kidney and probably of other organs by regulating the recruitment
CC       of mesenchymal cells into epithelial structures. It recognizes the
CC       sequence R-G-D in a wide array of ligands including TNC, FN1, SPP1
CC       TGFB1, TGFB3 and VTN. NPNT is probably its functional ligand in
CC       kidney genesis. Neuronal receptor for TNC it mediates cell-cell
CC       interactions and regulates neurite outgrowth of sensory and motor
CC       neurons. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10742111,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11470831, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11891185,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12787402, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17537792,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9054500, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9548928,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9614184}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Heterodimer of an alpha and a beta subunit. The alpha
CC       subunit is composed of a heavy and a light chain linked by a
CC       disulfide bond. Alpha-8 associates with beta-1.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10742111};
CC       Single-pass type I membrane protein {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10742111}.
CC       Cell membrane {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=2;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=A2ARA8-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2;
CC         IsoId=A2ARA8-2; Sequence=VSP_027364, VSP_027365;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available.;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: In brain, expressed in deep cortex,
CC       hippocampal CA1, basolateral amygdala and striatum. In kidney,
CC       expressed in glomerular mesengium (at protein level).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10024342, ECO:0000269|PubMed:10504498}.
CC   -!- DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE: Expressed in mesenchymal cells of developing
CC       organs such as gut, lung, gonads and nephrogenic cord.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14500699, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9054500}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Mice display renal agenesis and dysgenesis.
CC       This is associated with a reduced expression of Gdnf that is
CC       similarly found in mice lacking Npnt. Adult mice also display
CC       increased susceptibility to glomerular capillary destruction upon
CC       mechanical stress. Mice lacking Itga8 also have difficulty
CC       balancing associated with structural defects in the inner ear
CC       where utricular hair cells lack stereocilia.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10742111, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11891185,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17537792, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9054500}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the integrin alpha chain family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 7 FG-GAP repeats. {ECO:0000305}.

RA   Li M.D., Ruan H.B., Hughes M.E., Lee J.S., Singh J.P., Jones S.P.,

RN   [11]
RP   INTERACTION WITH TET1 AND TET2.
RX   PubMed=23352454; DOI=10.1016/j.molcel.2012.12.019;
RA   Vella P., Scelfo A., Jammula S., Chiacchiera F., Williams K.,
RA   Cuomo A., Roberto A., Christensen J., Bonaldi T., Helin K., Pasini D.;
RT   "Tet proteins connect the O-linked N-acetylglucosamine transferase Ogt
RT   to chromatin in embryonic stem cells.";
RL   Mol. Cell 49:645-656(2013).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Catalyzes the transfer of a single N-acetylglucosamine
CC       from UDP-GlcNAc to a serine or threonine residue in cytoplasmic
CC       and nuclear proteins resulting in their modification with a beta-
CC       linked N-acetylglucosamine (O-GlcNAc). Glycosylates a large and
CC       diverse number of proteins including histone H2B, AKT1, EZH2,
CC       PFKL, KMT2E/MLL5, MAPT/TAU and HCFC1. Can regulate their cellular
CC       processes via cross-talk between glycosylation and phosphorylation
CC       or by affecting proteolytic processing. Involved in insulin
CC       resistance in muscle and adipocyte cells via glycosylating insulin
CC       signaling components and inhibiting the 'Thr-308' phosphorylation
CC       of AKT1, enhancing IRS1 phosphorylation and attenuating insulin
CC       signaling. Involved in glycolysis regulation by mediating
CC       glycosylation of 6-phosphofructokinase PFKL, inhibiting its
CC       activity. Component of a THAP1/THAP3-HCFC1-OGT complex that is
CC       required for the regulation of the transcriptional activity of
CC       RRM1. Plays a key role in chromatin structure by mediating O-
CC       GlcNAcylation of 'Ser-112' of histone H2B: recruited to CpG-rich
CC       transcription start sites of active genes via its interaction with
CC       TET proteins (TET1, TET2 or TET3). As part of the NSL complex
CC       indirectly involved in acetylation of nucleosomal histone H4 on
CC       several lysine residues. O-GlcNAcylation of 'Ser-75' of EZH2
CC       increases its stability, and facilitating the formation of
CC       H3K27me3 by the PRC2/EED-EZH2 complex (By similarity). Regulates
CC       circadian oscillation of the clock genes and glucose homeostasis
CC       in the liver. Stabilizes clock proteins ARNTL/BMAL1 and CLOCK
CC       through O-glycosylation, which prevents their ubiquitination and
CC       subsequent degradation. Promotes the CLOCK-ARNTL/BMAL1-mediated
CC       transcription of genes in the negative loop of the circadian clock
CC       such as PER1/2 and CRY1/2. {ECO:0000250,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:23337503, ECO:0000269|PubMed:23395176}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: UDP-N-acetyl-D-glucosamine + [protein]-L-
CC       serine = UDP + [protein]-3-O-(N-acetyl-D-glucosaminyl)-L-serine.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: UDP-N-acetyl-D-glucosamine + [protein]-L-
CC       threonine = UDP + [protein]-3-O-(N-acetyl-D-glucosaminyl)-L-
CC       threonine.
CC   -!- PATHWAY: Protein modification; protein glycosylation.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Heterotrimer; consists of one 78 kDa subunit and two 110
CC       kDa subunits dimerized via TPR repeats 6 and 7 (By similarity).
CC       Component of the MLL5-L complex, at least composed of KMT2E/MLL5,
CC       STK38, PPP1CA, PPP1CB, HCFC1, PPP1CC and ACTB. Component of a
CC       THAP1/THAP3-HCFC1-OGT complex. Component of the NSL complex at
CC       least composed of MOF/KAT8, KANSL1, KANSL2, KANSL3, MCRS1, PHF20,
CC       OGT1/OGT, WDR5 and HCFC1. Interacts directly with HCFC1; the
CC       interaction O-glycosylates HCFC1, regulates its proteolytic
CC       processing and transcriptional activity and, in turn, stabilizes
CC       OGT in the nucleus. Interacts (via TPRs 1-6) with SIN3A; the
CC       interaction mediates transcriptional repression in parallel with
CC       histone deacetylase (By similarity). Interacts (via TPR 5-6) with
CC       TET1, TET2 and TET3. Interacts (via TPR repeats 6 and 7) with
CC       ATXN10. Interacts with ARNTL/BMAL1. {ECO:0000250,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16182253, ECO:0000269|PubMed:23337503,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:23352454}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000250}. Nucleus
CC       {ECO:0000250}. Cell membrane {ECO:0000250}. Note=Mostly in the
CC       nucleus. Retained in the nucleus via interaction with HCFC1. After
CC       insulin induction, translocated from the nucleus to the cell
CC       membrane via phophatidylinisotide binding. Colocalizes with AKT1
CC       at the plasma membrane (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=2;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=Q8CGY8-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2;
CC         IsoId=Q8CGY8-2; Sequence=VSP_024844;
CC   -!- INDUCTION: Expression in the liver oscillates in a circadian
CC       manner. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:23395176}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The TPR repeat domain is required for substrate binding
CC       and oligomerization. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- PTM: Ubiquitinated, leading to its proteasomal degradation.
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- PTM: Phosphorylation on Ser-3 or Ser-4 by GSK3-beta positively
CC       regulates its activity. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:23395175}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the glycosyltransferase 41 family. O-GlcNAc
CC       transferase subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 13 TPR repeats. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00339}.

RP   DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE.
RX   PubMed=22124607; DOI=10.1007/s00125-011-2386-z;
RA   Loh K., Merry T.L., Galic S., Wu B.J., Watt M.J., Zhang S.,
RA   Zhang Z.Y., Neel B.G., Tiganis T.;
RT   "T cell protein tyrosine phosphatase (TCPTP) deficiency in muscle does
RT   not alter insulin signalling and glucose homeostasis in mice.";
RL   Diabetologia 55:468-478(2012).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Non-receptor type tyrosine-specific phosphatase that
CC       dephosphorylates receptor protein tyrosine kinases including INSR,
CC       EGFR, CSF1R, PDGFR. Also dephosphorylates non-receptor protein
CC       tyrosine kinases like JAK1, JAK2, JAK3, Src family kinases, STAT1,
CC       STAT3, STAT5A, STAT5B and STAT6 either in the nucleus or the
CC       cytoplasm. Negatively regulates numerous signaling pathways and
CC       biological processes like hematopoiesis, inflammatory response,
CC       cell proliferation and differentiation, and glucose homeostasis.
CC       Plays a multifaceted and important role in the development of the
CC       immune system. Functions in T-cell receptor signaling through
CC       dephosphorylation of FYN and LCK to control T-cells
CC       differentiation and activation. Dephosphorylates CSF1R, negatively
CC       regulating its downstream signaling and macrophage
CC       differentiation. Negatively regulates cytokine (IL2/interleukin-2
CC       and interferon)-mediated signaling through dephosphorylation of
CC       the cytoplasmic kinases JAK1, JAK3 and their substrate STAT1, that
CC       propagate signaling downstream of the cytokine receptors. Also
CC       regulates the IL6/interleukin-6 and IL4/interleukin-4 cytokine
CC       signaling through dephosphorylation of STAT3 and STAT6
CC       respectively. In addition to the immune system, it is involved in
CC       anchorage-dependent, negative regulation of EGF-stimulated cell
CC       growth. Activated by the integrin ITGA1/ITGB1, it dephosphorylates
CC       EGFR and negatively regulates EGF signaling. Dephosphorylates
CC       PDGFRB and negatively regulates platelet-derived growth factor
CC       receptor-beta signaling pathway and therefore cell proliferation.
CC       Negatively regulates tumor necrosis factor-mediated signaling
CC       downstream via MAPK through SRC dephosphorylation. May also
CC       regulate the hepatocyte growth factor receptor signaling pathway
CC       through dephosphorylation of the hepatocyte growth factor receptor
CC       MET. Plays also an important role in glucose homeostasis. For
CC       instance, negatively regulates the insulin receptor signaling
CC       pathway through the dephosphorylation of INSR and control
CC       gluconeogenesis and liver glucose production through negative
CC       regulation of the IL6 signaling pathways. Finally, it negatively
CC       regulates prolactin-mediated signaling pathway through
CC       dephosphorylation of STAT5A and STAT5B. May also bind DNA.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11498795, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11773439,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11909529, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12138178,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:14966296, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15696169,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16705167, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17210636,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:20484139, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22080863,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9271584}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Protein tyrosine phosphate + H(2)O = protein
CC       tyrosine + phosphate. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU10044}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with RMDN3. Isoform 1 interacts with TMED9.
CC       Isoform 1 interacts with STX17; dephosphorylates STX17. Interacts
CC       with ITGA1 (via cytoplasmic domain); activates the phosphatase
CC       activity towards EGFR. Interacts with TRAF2; probably involved in
CC       tumor necrosis factor-mediated signaling. Interacts with MET (By
CC       similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Isoform 1: Endoplasmic reticulum
CC       {ECO:0000250}. Endoplasmic reticulum-Golgi intermediate
CC       compartment {ECO:0000250}. Note=Targeted to the endoplasmic
CC       reticulum by its C-terminal hydrophobic region. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Isoform 2: Nucleus {ECO:0000250}. Cytoplasm
CC       {ECO:0000250}. Cell membrane {ECO:0000250}. Note=Predominantly
CC       localizes to chromatin. Able to shuttle between the nucleus and
CC       the cytoplasm and to dephosphorylate plasma membrane receptors.
CC       Recruited by activated ITGA1 at the plasma membrane (By
CC       similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=2;
CC       Name=1; Synonyms=PTPB, TC-PTPb;
CC         IsoId=Q06180-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2; Synonyms=PTPA, TC-PTPa;
CC         IsoId=Q06180-2; Sequence=VSP_012367;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Ubiquitously expressed. The highest expression
CC       levels were found in ovary, testis, thymus and kidney.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:20484139, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9271584}.
CC   -!- PTM: Isoform 2: Specifically phosphorylated in a cell cycle-
CC       dependent manner by cyclin-dependent kinases. Probably activated
CC       through phosphorylation by PKR (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Newborn mice are viable and do not display
CC       physical abnormalities. However, by 3 to 5 weeks of age they
CC       develop hunched posture, diarrhea and anemia. They do not survive
CC       beyond 5 weeks of age due to severe anemia, hematopoietic defects
CC       and the development of progressive systemic inflammatory disease.
CC       They display splenomegaly, lymphadenopathy and thymic atrophy,
CC       associated with altered B-cell differentiation, altered
CC       erythropoiesis, and impaired T- and B-cell functions. The
CC       inflammatory disease is characterized by high levels of
CC       circulating proinflammatory cytokines and lymphocytic infiltrates
CC       in non-lymphoid tissues. Heterozygous Ptpn2+/- mice exhibit
CC       decreased gluconeogenesis and hepatic glucose production while
CC       muscle-specific disruption of Ptpn2 has no effect on insulin
CC       signaling and glucose homeostasis in this tissue.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14726372, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20484139,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22080863, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22124607,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9271584}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the protein-tyrosine phosphatase family.
CC       Non-receptor class 1 subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 tyrosine-protein phosphatase domain.
CC       {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU00160}.

CC       {ECO:0000250}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Essential component of the high affinity receptor for
CC       the general membrane fusion machinery and an important regulator
CC       of transport vesicle docking and fusion. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homotetramer (via coiled-coil domain), also forms
CC       heterotetramers with STX4 and VAMP3. Binds simultaneously to
CC       SNAPIN and SYN4. Found in a complex with VAMP8 and STX1A (By
CC       similarity). Binds tightly to multiple syntaxins and
CC       synaptobrevins/VAMPs. Found in a complex with VAMP8 and STX4 in
CC       pancreas. Interacts with STX1A and STX12. {ECO:0000250,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15363411, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9507000}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P70452:Stx4; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-1812522, EBI-645716;
CC       Q08850:Stx4 (xeno); NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-1812522, EBI-918243;
CC       P63044:Vamp2; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-1812522, EBI-521920;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane; Peripheral membrane protein.
CC       Cell membrane {ECO:0000250}; Lipid-anchor {ECO:0000250}. Cell
CC       junction, synapse, synaptosome. Note=Mainly localized to the
CC       plasma membrane.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed in non-neuronal tissues.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the SNAP-25 family. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 2 t-SNARE coiled-coil homology domains.
CC       {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU00202}.

RA   Rardin M.J., Newman J.C., Held J.M., Cusack M.P., Sorensen D.J.,
RA   Li B., Schilling B., Mooney S.D., Kahn C.R., Verdin E., Gibson B.W.;

RT   mitochondria identifies substrates of SIRT3 in metabolic pathways.";
RL   Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 110:6601-6606(2013).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: The branched-chain alpha-keto dehydrogenase complex
CC       catalyzes the overall conversion of alpha-keto acids to acyl-CoA
CC       and CO(2). It contains multiple copies of three enzymatic
CC       components: branched-chain alpha-keto acid decarboxylase (E1),
CC       lipoamide acyltransferase (E2) and lipoamide dehydrogenase (E3).
CC       Within this complex, the catalytic function of this enzyme is to
CC       accept, and to transfer to coenzyme A, acyl groups that are
CC       generated by the branched-chain alpha-keto acid decarboxylase
CC       component.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: 2-methylpropanoyl-CoA + enzyme N(6)-
CC       (dihydrolipoyl)lysine = CoA + enzyme N(6)-(S-(2-
CC       methylpropanoyl)dihydrolipoyl)lysine.
CC   -!- COFACTOR:
CC       Name=(R)-lipoate; Xref=ChEBI:CHEBI:83088; Evidence={ECO:0000250};
CC       Note=Binds 1 lipoyl cofactor covalently. {ECO:0000250};
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Forms a 24-polypeptide structural core with octahedral
CC       symmetry.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Mitochondrion matrix.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the 2-oxoacid dehydrogenase family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 lipoyl-binding domain.
CC       {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU01066, ECO:0000305}.

RP   INTERACTION WITH MAF.
RX   PubMed=9070273; DOI=10.1006/bbrc.1997.6097;
RA   Kurschner C., Morgan J.I.;
RT   "USF2/FIP associates with the b-Zip transcription factor, c-Maf, via
RT   its bHLH domain and inhibits c-Maf DNA binding activity.";
RL   Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 231:333-339(1997).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Transcription factor that binds to a symmetrical DNA
CC       sequence (E-boxes) (5'-CACGTG-3') that is found in a variety of
CC       viral and cellular promoters.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Efficient DNA binding requires dimerization with another
CC       bHLH protein. Binds DNA as a homodimer or a heterodimer
CC       (USF1/USF2). Interacts with MAF. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9070273}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P42225:Stat1; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-647583, EBI-647118;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=2;
CC         Comment=Additional isoforms seem to exist.;
CC       Name=USF2A;
CC         IsoId=Q64705-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=USF2B;
CC         IsoId=Q64705-2; Sequence=VSP_002166;
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 bHLH (basic helix-loop-helix) domain.
CC       {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU00981}.
CC   -!- SEQUENCE CAUTION:
CC       Sequence=AAA20493.1; Type=Erroneous initiation; Evidence={ECO:0000305};

RP   ACETYLATION [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS] AT LYS-122, AND IDENTIFICATION BY
RP   MASS SPECTROMETRY [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS].
RC   TISSUE=Embryonic fibroblast;
RX   PubMed=23806337; DOI=10.1016/j.molcel.2013.06.001;
RA   Park J., Chen Y., Tishkoff D.X., Peng C., Tan M., Dai L., Xie Z.,
RA   Zhang Y., Zwaans B.M., Skinner M.E., Lombard D.B., Zhao Y.;
RT   "SIRT5-mediated lysine desuccinylation impacts diverse metabolic
RT   pathways.";
RL   Mol. Cell 50:919-930(2013).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Transcription factor involved in the transcriptional
CC       regulation of osmoprotective and inflammatory genes. Regulates
CC       hypertonicity-induced cellular accumulation of osmolytes.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11934689, ECO:0000269|PubMed:14983020}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homodimer when bound to DNA, completely encircles its DNA
CC       target. Does not bind with Fos and Jun transcription factors.
CC       Interacts with CIDEC; this interaction is direct and retains NFAT5
CC       in the cytoplasm (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11934689}.
CC       Cytoplasm {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11934689}. Note=Nuclear distribution
CC       increases under hypertonic conditions.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=4;
CC         Comment=Additional isoforms seem to exist. Experimental
CC         confirmation may be lacking for some isoforms.;
CC       Name=1; Synonyms=C;
CC         IsoId=Q9WV30-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC         Note=May have longer half-life and is more efficient in
CC         stimulation of transcription than isoform 3.;
CC       Name=2; Synonyms=D;
CC         IsoId=Q9WV30-2; Sequence=VSP_053212;
CC       Name=3; Synonyms=A;
CC         IsoId=Q9WV30-3; Sequence=VSP_053211;
CC       Name=4;
CC         IsoId=Q9WV30-4; Sequence=VSP_053213, VSP_053214;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Detected in white and brown adipose tissue,
CC       muscle, heart, liver and kidney. Expressed in lymphocytes (at
CC       protein level). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14983020,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:23233732}.
CC   -!- DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE: At 10.5 dpc, expressed in brain and
CC       developing lens. At 12.5 dpc, the expression is extended to liver.
CC       By 17.5 dpc, expressed abundantly in brain, spinal cord, heart end
CC       liver and moderately in salivary gland, lung, kidney, gut and
CC       bladder (at protein level). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11934689}.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: Up-regulated upon hypertonic conditions, this up-
CC       regulation in not observed in ES cells.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11934689, ECO:0000269|PubMed:23233732}.
CC   -!- PTM: Phosphorylated at Thr-135 by CDK5 in response to osmotic
CC       stress; this phosphorylation mediates its rapid nuclear
CC       localization.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Embryonic and perinatal lethality with
CC       incomplete penetrance. At 17.5 dpc, 50% of the expected Mendelian
CC       rate with only 3.4% of the expected number living past 21 days
CC       after birth. The few survivors to adulthood fail to thrive and
CC       their weight is half compared to the wild-type. At 3 weeks old,
CC       kidney hypoplasia and an altered medullary morphology are observed
CC       with an increased apoptosis in the kidney inner medulla. Under
CC       osmotic stress, the transcriptional regulation of osmoprotective
CC       genes is altered in the kidney medulla.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14983020}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 RHD (Rel-like) domain.
CC       {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU00265}.
CC   -!- SEQUENCE CAUTION:
CC       Sequence=AAF31405.1; Type=Erroneous initiation; Note=Translation N-terminally extended.; Evidence={ECO:0000305};
CC       Sequence=EDL11405.1; Type=Erroneous gene model prediction; Evidence={ECO:0000305};

RA   Fanis P., Gillemans N., Aghajanirefah A., Pourfarzad F., Demmers J.,
RA   Esteghamat F., Vadlamudi R.K., Grosveld F., Philipsen S.,
RA   van Dijk T.B.;
RT   "Five friends of methylated chromatin target of protein-arginine-
RT   methyltransferase[prmt]-1 (chtop), a complex linking arginine
RT   methylation to desumoylation.";
RL   Mol. Cell. Proteomics 11:1263-1273(2012).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Involved in the biogenesis of the 60S ribosomal subunit.
CC       Required for maturation of the 28S rRNA (By similarity). Functions
CC       as a component of the Five Friends of Methylated CHTOP (5FMC)
CC       complex; the 5FMC complex is recruited to ZNF148 by methylated
CC       CHTOP, leading to desumoylation of ZNF148 and subsequent
CC       transactivation of ZNF148 target genes. {ECO:0000250,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22872859}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of some MLL1/MLL complex, at least composed of
CC       the core components KMT2A/MLL1, ASH2L, HCFC1/HCF1, WDR5 and RBBP5,
CC       as well as the facultative components BAP18, CHD8, E2F6, HSP70,
CC       INO80C, KANSL1, LAS1L, MAX, MCRS1, MGA, MYST1/MOF, PELP1, PHF20,
CC       PRP31, RING2, RUVB1/TIP49A, RUVB2/TIP49B, SENP3, TAF1, TAF4, TAF6,
CC       TAF7, TAF9 and TEX10 (By similarity). Component of the 5FMC
CC       complex, at least composed of PELP1, LAS1L, TEX10, WDR18 and
CC       SENP3; the complex interacts with methylated CHTOP and ZNF148.
CC       {ECO:0000250, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22872859}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus, nucleolus {ECO:0000250}. Nucleus,
CC       nucleoplasm {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22872859}. Cytoplasm
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22872859}. Note=Localizes mainly to the
CC       granular component, the region implicated in the later steps of
CC       rRNA processing and subunit assembly and export (By similarity).
CC       Mainly found in the nucleoplasm, with low levels detected in the
CC       cytoplasmic and chromatin fractions. {ECO:0000250}.

RP   PHOSPHORYLATION IN RESPONSE TO FLT3 SIGNALING.
RX   PubMed=21262971; DOI=10.1074/jbc.M110.205021;

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Mediates the production of the second messenger
CC       molecules diacylglycerol (DAG) and inositol 1,4,5-trisphosphate
CC       (IP3). Plays an important role in the regulation of intracellular
CC       signaling cascades. Becomes activated in response to ligand-
CC       mediated activation of receptor-type tyrosine kinases, such as
CC       PDGFRA, PDGFRB, FGFR1, FGFR2, FGFR3 and FGFR4. Plays a role in
CC       actin reorganization and cell migration.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15308098}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: 1-phosphatidyl-1D-myo-inositol 4,5-
CC       bisphosphate + H(2)O = 1D-myo-inositol 1,4,5-trisphosphate +
CC       diacylglycerol.
CC   -!- COFACTOR:
CC       Name=Ca(2+); Xref=ChEBI:CHEBI:29108;
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: Activated by phosphorylation on tyrosine
CC       residues.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts (via SH2 domain) with FGFR1, FGFR2, FGFR3 and
CC       FGFR4 (phosphorylated). Interacts with RALGPS1. Interacts (via SH2
CC       domains) with VIL1 (phosphorylated at C-terminus tyrosine
CC       phosphorylation sites). Interacts (via SH2 domain) with RET (By
CC       similarity). Interacts with AGAP2 via its SH3 domain. Interacts
CC       with LAT (phosphorylated) upon TCR activation. Interacts (via SH3
CC       domain) with the Pro-rich domain of TNK1. Associates with BLNK,
CC       VAV1, GRB2 and NCK1 in a B-cell antigen receptor-dependent
CC       fashion. Interacts with CBLB in activated T-cells; which inhibits
CC       phosphorylation. Interacts with SHB. Interacts (via SH3 domain)
CC       with the Arg/Gly-rich-flanked Pro-rich domains of KHDRBS1/SAM68.
CC       This interaction is selectively regulated by arginine methylation
CC       of KHDRBS1/SAM68. Interacts with INPP5D/SHIP1, THEMIS and CLNK.
CC       Interacts with FLT4 and KIT. Interacts with AXL (By similarity).
CC       Interacts with SYK; activates PLCG1 (By similarity). Interacts
CC       with FLT1 (tyrosine-phosphorylated). Interacts (via SH2 domain)
CC       with PDGFRA and PDGFRB (tyrosine phosphorylated). Interacts with
CC       PIP5K1C. Interacts with NTRK1 and NTRK2 (phosphorylated upon
CC       ligand-binding). Interacts with TESPA1 (By similarity). Interacts
CC       with GRB2, LAT and THEMIS upon TCR activation in thymocytes; the
CC       association is weaker in the absence of TESPA1. {ECO:0000250,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:10646608, ECO:0000269|PubMed:10748127,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11463797, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12367511,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15629145, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16000869,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:1646396, ECO:0000269|PubMed:1714377,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17620338, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17635937,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19597499, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22561606,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8943348, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9299537}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P14753:Epor; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-300133, EBI-617901;
CC       Q60631:Grb2; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-300133, EBI-1688;
CC       O54957:Lat; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-300133, EBI-6390034;
CC       P48356:Lepr; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-300133, EBI-2257257;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell projection, lamellipodium
CC       {ECO:0000250}. Cell projection, ruffle {ECO:0000250}. Note=Rapidly
CC       redistributed to ruffles and lamellipodia structures in response
CC       to epidermal growth factor (EGF) treatment. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The SH3 domain mediates interaction with RALGPS1 (By
CC       similarity). The SH3 domain also mediates interaction with CLNK.
CC       {ECO:0000250, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11463797}.
CC   -!- PTM: Tyrosine phosphorylated in response to signaling via
CC       activated FLT3, KIT and PDGFRA (By similarity). Tyrosine
CC       phosphorylated by activated FGFR1, FGFR2, FGFR3 and FGFR4.
CC       Tyrosine phosphorylated by activated FLT1 and KDR. Tyrosine
CC       phosphorylated by activated PDGFRB. The receptor-mediated
CC       activation of PLCG1 involves its phosphorylation by tyrosine
CC       kinases in response to ligation of a variety of growth factor
CC       receptors and immune system receptors. For instance, SYK
CC       phosphorylates and activates PLCG1 in response to ligation of the
CC       B-cell receptor. Phosphorylated by ITK and TXK on Tyr-783 upon TCR
CC       activation in T-cells. May be dephosphorylated by PTPRJ (By
CC       similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- PTM: Ubiquitinated by CBLB in activated T-cells.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15308098}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 C2 domain. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00041}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 EF-hand domain. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00448}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 2 PH domains. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00145}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 PI-PLC X-box domain. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00270}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 PI-PLC Y-box domain. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00271}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 2 SH2 domains. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00191}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 SH3 domain. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00192}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Molecular chaperone; assists the folding of proteins
CC       upon ATP hydrolysis. As part of the BBS/CCT complex may play a
CC       role in the assembly of BBSome, a complex involved in ciliogenesis
CC       regulating transports vesicles to the cilia. Known to play a role,
CC       in vitro, in the folding of actin and tubulin (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Heterooligomeric complex of about 850 to 900 kDa that
CC       forms two stacked rings, 12 to 16 nm in diameter. Interacts with
CC       PACRG. Component of the BBS/CCT complex composed at least of MKKS,
CC       BBS10, BBS12, TCP1, CCT2, CCT3, CCT4, CCT5 AND CCT8 (By
CC       similarity). Interacts with DYX1C1. {ECO:0000250,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:23872636}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000250}. Cytoplasm,
CC       cytoskeleton, microtubule organizing center, centrosome
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the TCP-1 chaperonin family. {ECO:0000305}.
